contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox mineral | name = Oligoclase | category = [[plagioclase]], [[feldspar]], [[tectosilicate]] | boxwidth = | boxbgcolor = | image = Oligoclase-4jg47a.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Oligoclase from Chihuahua, Mexico | formula = ([[calcium|Ca]],[[sodium|Na]])([[aluminum|Al]],[[silicon|Si]])<sub>4</sub>[[oxygen|O]]<sub>8</sub>, where [[calcium|Ca]]/([[calcium|Ca]] + [[sodium|Na]]) (% [[anorthite]]) is between 10%–30% | molweight = | color = usually white, with shades of grey, green, or red. | habit = | system = | twinning = | cleavage = | fracture = | tenacity = | mohs = 6 to 6.5 | luster = | polish = | refractive = nα=1.533–1.543; nβ=1.537–1.548; nγ=1.542–1.552 | opticalprop = | birefringence = 1st order | dispersion = | pleochroism = | fluorescence= | absorption = | streak = | gravity = 2.64 to 2.66 | density = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | diaphaneity = | other = | references = }} '''Oligoclase''' is a rock-forming [[mineral]] belonging to the [[plagioclase]] [[feldspar]]s. In chemical composition and in its crystallographic and physical characters it is intermediate between [[albite]] ([[sodium|Na]][[aluminum|Al]][[silicon|Si]]<sub>3</sub>[[oxygen|O]]<sub>8</sub>) and [[anorthite]] ([[calcium|Ca]]Al<sub>2</sub>Si<sub>2</sub>O<sub>8</sub>). The albite:anorthite molar ratio ranges from 90:10 to 70:30. Oligoclase is a high sodium feldspar crystallizing in the [[triclinic]] system. The [[Mohs hardness]] is 6 to 6.5 and the [[specific gravity]] is 2.64 to 2.66. The [[refractive index|refractive indices]] are: nα=1.533–1.543, nβ=1.537–1.548, and nγ=1.542–1.552. In color it is usually white, with shades of grey, green, or red. ==Name and discovery== The name oligoclase was given by [[August Breithaupt]] in 1826 from the Greek ''oligos'', little, and ''clasein'', to break, because the mineral was thought to have a less perfect cleavage than albite. It had previously been recognized as a distinct species by [[J. J. Berzelius]] in 1824, and was named by him soda-spodumene (Natron-spodumen), because of its resemblance in appearance to [[spodumene]]. ==Occurrence== Perfectly colorless and transparent glassy material found at [[Bakersville, North Carolina]] has occasionally been faceted as a [[gemstone]]. Another variety more frequently used as a gemstone is the [[aventurine]]-feldspar or sun-stone found as reddish cleavage masses in [[gneiss]] at [[Tvedestrand]] in southern [[Norway]]; this presents a brilliant red to golden metallic glitter, due to the presence of numerous small scales of [[hematite]] oriented within the feldspar structure. Oligoclase occurs, often accompanying [[orthoclase]], as a constituent of plutonic [[igneous rock]]s such as [[granite]], [[syenite]], and [[diorite]]. It occurs in [[porphyry (geology)|porphyry]] and [[diabase]] [[dike (geology)|dikes]] and [[sill (geology)|sills]] as well as in the [[volcanic]] rocks [[andesite]] and [[trachyte]]. It also occurs in gneiss. The best developed and largest crystals are those found with orthoclase, [[quartz]], [[epidote]], and [[calcite]] in veins in granite at [[Arendal]] in Norway. The distinctive texture of [[rapakivi granite]] is due to oligoclase rims on orthoclase [[phenocryst]]s. Oligoclase is also found in [[metamorphic rocks]] formed under transitional [[greenschist]] to [[amphibolite]] facies conditions. ==Schiller iridescence== Some examples show Schiller iridescence due to the presence of [[exsolution]] lamellae on cooling in the peristerite miscibility gap, ~An<sub>5</sub>-An<sub>18</sub>. ==References== *{{1911}} *Hurlbut, Cornelius S.; Klein, Cornelis, 1985, ''Manual of Mineralogy'', 20th ed., Wiley, ISBN 0-471-80580-7 *[http://webmineral.com/data/Oligoclase.shtml Webmineral data] *[http://mineral.galleries.com/minerals/silicate/oligocla/oligocla.htm Mineral galleries] *[http://www.mindat.org/min-2976.html Mindat] [[Category:Tectosilicates]] [[Category:Sodium minerals]] [[Category:Calcium minerals]] [[Category:Feldspar]] [[Category:Triclinic minerals]] {{silicate-mineral-stub}}
